A different sort of Christmas 🎄

And a reminder this is my highlight, my best photos! What they don’t show you is the stressful car rides with Joshua hating the car seat, my inner critique which seemed to be huge on Christmas Eve and sitting round on Boxing Day when I was hit with such a huge amount of grief 

My huge takeaway from this Christmas is less pressure, less focus on food and the day being done in a certain way and more relaxed which means more fun! My husband and I have lots of ideas for next Christmas now!! 🙈

🎄🎄🎄

#christmas #december #mentalhealthmatters #mha

There have been so many times when I have stood in a cafe looking at the food longing for something, so many times when I have thought about food non-stop… I would be going through my day to day with food on my mind wondering if I was ever going to stop thinking about it.. I felt like a bad person with an eating disorder especially in recovery as surely others weren’t like this … i felt abnormal to my friends as surely they weren’t like this …

… the first time round in recovery I just sat with all these feelings and thoughts but true recovery and going all in is about eating when that mental hunger hits. There is a reason you are thinking about the food. 

I make it sound so easy, if you are thinking about food… eat.. but I also know how hard this is in practise. 

I am going to unpack this more over the next few days but for now this is your reminder that if you are thinking about food you need to eat even if it feels scary and hard! Even if others aren’t eating in they moment, you need to eat! I promise, it will help your whole recovery journey!

Last night we landed in New Zealand and I had a huge amount of discomfort in my body. We dropped our bags off and headed for dinner. It was one of those days where I felt like I had just eaten and not moved - something that is totally normal to do but for me it had made me feel a bit out of sorts. 

We had a quick google and walked to the end of the road for a meal. The easy option for me would have been to go to the supermarket and by something packaged but I also knew I wanted to be able to do these things. To be able to be a Mum who can do stuff like this. 

We ordered, ended up taking it home and eating it whilst Joshua fed and fell asleep. Another opportunity to easily pretend I was full. But I pushed through these thoughts from the eating disorder and sat with the discomfort knowing that not only it would pass, but that other things were probably going on. 

Today we are heading to an island near Auckland so in between playing in the beach with Joshua I will take some time to work out what is actually going on with the discomfort. 

This is your reminder if you find a meal hard to ask yourself what it might be trying to tell you, to realise that if it’s hard you probably still have some work to do and to show yourself kindness in this space.

Following on from my post a few days ago, a lot of you have been in touch asking for more ways to sit with uncertainty, the fears, and all the discomfort the eating disorder gives. 

I wish I could tell you how long this process would last, how long you would feel this way. 

I wish I had all the answers, a one step guide to managing it, but the truth is I can’t. 

For me what helps in the immediate (which I mentioned earlier) if it is a discomfort around food, is reminding myself of why I am working at recovery, and reminding myself how awful the eating disorder was and that it never actually made me happy. 

Remember this will be unique to you and doesn’t replace but therapy but a few things that help me in the long term: 

🪧 Distractions 
🪧 Someone bringing me into a conversation if it is over a meal time and I am not engaged 
🪧Find a way to stay present in the here and now - this maybe deep breathing, counting 5 things you see, feel and smell, following the outline of your hand back and forth until you feel grounded or saying something out loud
🪧Talking it out - sometimes for me this is saying “I feel X” and that being it 
🪧Be aware that your anxiety and fears may be a what if scenario not an actual this is what will happen 
🪧focussing on the positives of recovery, the increased energy, the not thinking about food, remembering that uncertainty doesn’t have to be a negative thing 
🪧Staying off my phone as I am conscious that I will compare and contrast to others 
🪧Identifying what is actually going on, why am I feeling this why. 
🪧Having a weekly check in window to journal 
🪧Riding it out knowing that I have got through it before 

Uncertainty is hard, and in recovery it can feel like it adds a whole other layer to it but please know that you can do this. Not only does it get easier but recovery is also amazing!

This is me after Joshua was born. The me who was feeling lost, scared & alone. The me that had so much love for this tiny human but was often paralysed by fear. 

This is me longing for time to myself with my little one. Longing for bedtime so I could go upstairs & settle him & feel safe

This is me with no boundaries watching people passing my baby round like some sort of toy. Watching him have his photo taken countless times as our hearts searched for each others. This is me reaching for him as he cried out for me in someone else’s arms & feeling stuck when they wouldn’t give him back. The broken, quiet me with no boundaries or confidence

This is me healing from the emergency induction, healing from my time in NICU worrying about what sort of mum I was going to be. The me who felt like I had already failed at being a Mum. The me who felt safer in NICU but also longed to be home.

The me who sat & held my baby for days on end, feeding him, judging myself for my own parenting style. The me who noticed the frustrated eyes when we were having lunch and he was asleep on me in the sling or those eyes that rolled when I moved away to feed him. The me who wondered why some people had stopped asking how I was and only showed an interest in my baby. The me who longed for a conversation about something in the world, the me that was tired of hiding the emotions and fear I felt.

This is the me who cried to my Mum and sister when Joshua was waking every hour, the me who looked on at other people’s sleeping babies wondering why mine wasn’t sleeping much. Was it something I was doing wrong?

The me who wishes that if I could do it all again I would have listened to my own needs and put them first. I would have the confidence to say no, to setting my boundaries and to not beating myself up for things I had done.

The me who would have changed the narrative acknowledging that yes I found pregnancy hard but this doesn’t mean I don’t love my child; I gave everything I had to do my best for Joshua, which was showing so much love and care for him before he even was born. 

This is the me nearly 7 months on who would have showed the me at the start a whole load more kindness x

🏖️ + 🍉 + ☀️ = ❤️

Driving east today in the camper van and can’t believe how soon our trip ends! 

It has had its challenges with a baby and mentally but going at our own pace, sitting watching the world go by, been able to just do things with no real structure or routine and the huge amounts of outside time! 

Feeling very mixed about coming home from having to see triggering people, the uncertainty of our plan as we don’t really know what we are going to do, and also aware of my want to recover fully which maybe has been different doing in our own little bubble and worried about how this looks at home… I know that I need to be hyper aware of the eating disorder at this time trying to suck me back, offering me that sense of numbness and closeness. 

With that in mind I need to work out me and my mental health plan (this isn’t in replacement of therapy) - for me on this prep time it will include: 

📝 Making a list of all my worries 
📝Making a list of all the unknowns 
📝Booking in a few nice things 
📝Establishing boundaries 
📝Reminding myself why I want to get well 
📝Working out what I will do for myself each week when I am back!

Recovery this week has been about continuing to eat when I am hungry or thinking about food! It’s meant lots of resting and sitting with all the feelings round that. And has meant my husband going to choose dinners for us (mainly because I keep getting nap trapped!) 

🧠 🧠 

One of the things I am finding the hardest in this is the hunger. There have been so many points in life when I have not acted on mental hunger but the plan with doing this properly is about respecting that hunger! It’s about not fighting it, or trying to full up on low calorie food. It’s about pushing through it even when it feels uncomfortable. (More on this later!) 

How is recovery or supporting someone with recovery feeling for you at the moment?

I spent a lot of my life and recovery from anorexia with this fear of weight gain and because of this struggled to shift the marker that had been set for me when I was in treatment at the age of 17…

…. I was afraid of the unknown, afraid of properly trusting my body and myself and afraid of taking a risk … 

… because of this, not only did my brain not get the chance to rewire, but I yo-yo-ed round in this state of uncertainty, in a state of tinkering on the edge of relapse most of the time… afraid of what would happen if I broke the rules the eating disorder had created…. 

… in recovery it’s hard, and particularly hard when we have done things a certain way, and when services or society tell us a certain weight / size is healthy for our bodies, but tinkering round these weights won’t help us recover. 

Yes, services need to change the way they do things and focus on how a person is feeling emotionally over their weight, but as individuals (and trust me I know how hard this is), we need to find a way to communicate… 

… if I could go back in time I wish that I had put on more weight in recovery, trusting the process and allowing my brain the chance to recover… although of course easier said than done as eating disorders aren’t a choice! 

… for you, I encourage you to have that flexibility around weight restoration and to take that risk to overshoot! I encourage you to give this a go because this gives your brain the chance to mend and restore. And gives you a better chance of freedom! 

I am on this journey now! It’s scary, but exciting and I have expectations that things will be more than okay on the other side for you and for me!

“So I am going to order X but without XYZ and will swap X for that and then have X on the side” 

Sound familiar? 

This has been me for decades … I won’t go into specifics but the thought of something that I would count as an extra or something that wasn’t “necessary” caused such a fear that I would rather have dry food … the thought of having a dressing or butters because I wouldn’t know exactly how much was poured on … but in line with pushing to fully recover I know this is something I have to crack. So the last few days when we have gone out for food I have ordered meals straight as they are! 

It can feel hard to do this and I have certainly had moments when I am like do I really need to do this! But having an eating disorder is not a legitimate reason to order food without XYZ on it! 

I know this will feel terrifying and impossible for some of you and trust me I totally get that. Even when my breakfast arrived this morning and I looked down at all the sauce I had this initial panic, I was like how will this fit with the rest of the day? What does this mean for me? For my body? For my emotions? 

I am learning to sit with this and trust it, listening to my body is getting easier and remembering that these feelings always pass. 

Starting with this can feel hard, so why don’t you write down your fears around this, work out what’s really going on, and then create a safe space with a safe person to start to challenge the thinking. 

And always remembering the more we do it the easier it gets!

I got nap trapped the other evening  so had to let my husband go and choose dinner … this is becoming a common occurrence this trip and each time I have my dinner chosen it gets easier! 

If the thought of letting someone else sort your dinner out causes you anxiety, use this as a sign that something needs to change! 

… and remember whilst at first it feels uncomfortable and hard, it does get easier!

This is something that I am hearing more and more of and it’s just not okay!  It’s the heartbreaking reality that so many are being faced with right now! Not only are people still being turned away from services if they don’t have a specific BMI but now if they “don’t recover fast enough” the same is happening … 
 
Eating disorders are not a choice, they are not someone choosing to be difficult! 

My heart breaks for all these people, this was me - not only did I think recovery wouldn’t be possible, but i often didn’t know if I wanted to. I couldn’t imagine a life outside of it… a life where I would feel things… a life of freedom and no fear… I had support and help but some days it still felt too hard … but we cannot give up on anyone

… the stigma around eating disorders is real, but now we are seeing it in services too! 

Sending love to each and everyone of you! You deserve to recover and you deserve the support to help you get there! And to those supporting people with eating disorders, please know none of this is a choice, please be patient and compassionate … please give them space to recover psychologically and physically! 

*all this said with the utmost respect and appreciation of how amazing the nhs is and with knowledge of funding issues etc

“Hi my name is Hope Virgo and I struggle around people who I don’t feel safe in-front of with last minute meal plan changes & when my feelings aren’t taken seriously & I am not heard …” 

This is a statement I have been thinking about over the last few months and something I have been speaking to my husband about. And perhaps this is me owning some part of these final steps in my recovery creating safe spaces for me but also pushing for full recovery so realising I can’t always be in control of these situations! 

Reflecting on the last few years, I have progressed so much and probably only have a tiny way to go to hit being fully recovery which is so exciting! But there are still some things I find hard, and particularly being pregnant and with life stuff this year I have had to learn to navigate and understand the eating disorder more but also accept some people won’t ever really understand it. 

It’s interesting when we think about eating disorders because they are not about food but because something is going on. So when I find it harder to eat a meal with some people it’s normally because there is a heightened space of emotion! Perhaps some unresolved history or a level of unsafe feelings … honestly this goes for these people cooking for me, eating out with them feels harder and any food around .. 

In recovery it is important that we can create safe space so we can eat in all situations and this is something I am being to navigate more and think about with going home. I have had a safety place with eating the last few months, a bubble which at some point we will have to step out of. I will share more on this soon, but wanted to name it so that others not only feel less alone but also so that if you are supporting someone with an eating disorder you can understand that this happens. It isn’t us being difficult but much more complicated than that!

In those moments when life feels too much, when recovery feels too hard, when it feels too much of a risk, when the uncertainty takes over… 

… when you aren’t sure you can do it anymore … 

… please find a way to keep fighting ..

… I know it’s hard and so much of it is sitting with these intense emotions … but on top of that, what helps me is… 

.. Counting to 10 and reminding myself of my reasons to recover. Reminding myself of the freedom that can come, the laughter, the energy, the happiness… reminding myself that the eating disorder never solved anything .. reminding myself of the travelling I want to do… of the practical things such as eating lunches out with friends, being okay with last minute changes to plans … but beyond that it’s the headspace away from the eating disorder to focus on things I actually want to think about .. 

… the reasons to recover are endless and whilst I know eating disorders are not a choice sometimes hanging onto these reasons might just be what you need to get through that moment! 

*please remember this isn’t a replacement for therapy, and is something that works for me

This week is eating disorder awareness week in the UK and we would love your help to raise awareness of those affected by eating disorders! 

Eating disorders are the deadliest mental illnesses but the funding and support they receive has never met the demand. 

Enough is enough! We cannot and will not let eating disorders be ignored anymore! 

This eating disorder awareness week, we are asking you to support those affected by eating disorders in 3 ways: 

📧 Sign and share the open letter on your social media. Link here and in my stories : https://the.organise.network/campaigns/network-no-one-should-be-dying-of-an-eating-disorder-in-2023-8fffc72793b87a94?utm_campaign=eqsgJorTNd&utm_medium=whatsapp&utm_s
####

🎤Ask your followers to sign up to the UKs first ever eating disorders March. Info here and in my stories: https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/join-us-to-march-and-fight-for-those-affected-by-eating-disorders-tickets-526987151757

📸 Take a photo holding up a sign saying “I am supporting everyone affected by eating disorders because no one should be dying from an eating disorder in 2023 #dumpthescales “ 
 
⭐️⭐️⭐️

Thank you so much for your support!  Swipe right to see some graphics you can use on your social media this week! And be sure to use the #dumpthescales hashtag so we can share! 

Together we can and will end the injustices that so many face!

We often talk about our motivations to get well. What do we want from our future? Well what if I suggested you flipped it on its head. What if I suggested instead of talking about what motivates us why don’t instead we think about what would happen in 5 years if we weren’t recovered? If we were still in this space? 

As I think about this I am conscious of the eating disorder trying to romanticise things. Trying to make me believe that it would just be wonderful in five years that life would be amazing. But I know that is not true. 

Instead, I would be exhausted. I would have no energy, I would be constantly thinking about food unable to be in the moment spending most of my life calculating. I would be exhausted of moving. I would be longing for a chance to lay for hours in bed. I would have missed out on so much of life, would have had to come up with multiple excuses as to why I wasn’t eaten XYZ to Joshua. I would have missed out on creating so many new memories with those round me. 

I could go on … i know the future with the eating disorder can feel like the only option that you might not see a wait out, or maybe you think you can have it all, but the eating disorder will actually keep us stuck. 

Why don’t you take a moment this week to think this over and work out what sort of future you want? 

I know how I phrase things may see brutal at times that maybe I make it out to be really easy and if really isn’t, but it’s only because I know that freedom is there for everyone!

I have shared bit of this before but i felt prompted to share a bit more, I really hope it helps someone …

… as some of you will know I was sexually abused at the age of 12. After it finished I sat with these feelings they there was something categorically wrong with who I was and so I longed to change something… here is when I jump in to remind you that whilst sexual abuse left me with these feelings, it could be anything that makes you feel that there is something categorically wrong with you .. it could be the way your parents treated you; maybe you were bullied, never lived up to grades, maybe you never saw yourself represented on social media… and maybe for you you wanted to try and find this fix… so you thought if I change my body, if I fixate on food, if I exercise more then everything will be okay … 

… so you start to micromanage your food, your start to set your alarm earlier and earlier, but nothing works… the feelings don’t really subside… but you keep believing the reason something happened was because there is something wrong with you and so you keep trying.. 

… food, exercise, changing your body anything like that … it won’t fix things. It won’t take away what happened or take away that narrative… trust me I know! I have tried it all…

… and honestly working through this narrative, through the pain is hard. It is uncomfortable but we mustn’t let what someone did to us define our future. So next time that narrative starts, call it out, rework it, look at the evidence against it, interrupt it and surround yourself with the right people! It’s hard work shifting a narrative and I am not quite there yet with it but getting there! So here is me on this messy but exciting journey of life changing things in my brain!

Just because I have had an eating disorder for over half my life, it doesn’t mean that it defines me and it certainly doesn’t mean I will be in a state of recovery for the rest of my life! 

This week has been all about challenging myself further and still working to re-wire my brain fully to get rid of final eating disorder thoughts 

🥣 It’s been putting my porridge in the microwave and walking away from the kitchen not worrying that someone will tamper with it 

💦 It’s been letting my Mum cook for me and eating it despite what dressing she puts on it or what she has cooked it in 

🥐 It’s ordering last minute snacks or picking up last minute meals when I am out with Joshua as I didn’t have time to prep bits 

🥖 It’s been eating with Joshua and having what he haves, sharing crumpets, toast and bananas without worrying about portions 

🥘 It’s been leaving dinner half way through to go and cuddle Joshua when he wakes up and not worrying that someone will add more to my plate 

🧠 It’s been allowing myself to feel what I feel and communicating what’s going on

🖊️It’s been setting boundaries and feeling confident to do that putting my self worth up there as important 

📸 photo from Sydney before Christmas 🎄

I didn't reach out for help until I was 33 but going through therapy made me realise and come to terms with the fact that I had been struggling with eating disorders since the age of 7 years old. Turns out I had anorexia and body dysmorphia, a nasty bully who had lived inside my head and since I had never not known a time when she wasn't around the biggest challenge I faced when I was in therapy was what would I be without her? Would I be anything atall? 

Reaching out for help for me was a huge battle, I'd put it off for years and years, there's so much stigma surrounding it and I was so worried that a doctor or nurse would laugh at me or wonder why on earth I was going forward for help, that there was nothing wrong with me atall. You see I wasn't someone you would look at and say she's got anorexia, I wasn't underweight at the time, I would of been described as a healthy  woman, but that is the biggest mistake people make, you can't tell someone has an eating disorder just by looking at them.

My first outlet for help was the charity BEAT and without them and the wonderful person I spoke to on the other side, I wouldnt be here today. It took me a couple of weeks after this to eventually contact the doctor where I had to be weighed which is something I still struggle with to this day. 
However once I was in therapy the progress I made was intense and fast!
I felt as though I was making giant leaps.

I came out of therapy 2 years ago and I feel like a different person now, though there are bumps in the road and days I really struggled therapy has given me the tools to be able to move forward and to not let the eating disorders overcome me, her voice in my head got less and less over time and I'm believing that eventually she won't be there atall anymore.

Reach out for help if you're struggling, talk to someone you trust, noone will think that you are stupid, once you get that help that's when you're life can truly begin!

“The inaction to truly tackle mental health issues, and the epidemic that we face is killing people… 
 
…Access to treatment is a fundamental human right yet so many people are without it…”

🎤 🎤🎤🎤

Last night I presented evidence at the APPG for Fit & Healthy Childhood. The focus of the session was the abandonment of the mental health plan. 

I shared at length why we cannot ignore eating disorders, how we need a stand-alone strategy to tackle them, but also how they cut across so many (if not all) sectors of society. I talked about the stigmas and shame that are wrapped up in them and how they are hidden in plain sight. And I talked about why prevention in all of this is key!

…and even though it was an APPG focussed on children, I emphasised that adults get eating disorders and this needs to be tackled urgently too! 

I shared some of your experiences and talked about the recent stigmas we are seeing in parts of the nhs which leaves those affected by eating disorders with no support to get well. 

I often get frustrated with how long things take to change, with how long it takes for the government and parts of the nhs to tackle eating disorders with any sense of urgency. But that’s why I keep fighting and keep campaigning. 

That’s why we must not stop fighting these injustices because the more noise we make, the more chance we have of making change. 

it was  brilliant to speak alongside @mqmentalhealth and @mentalhealthfoundation 

📸Joshua being super wonderful and listening to me go on about eating disorders. MPs should follow his example (although maybe with less sandwich dropping on the floor!)

Thank you Nikki for bringing to light a topic that is so rarely discussed ❤️

I started my recovery at 30. 

My eating disorder began when I was 14 as activity based anorexia when I joined an athletics team

I quickly developed a very unhealthy relationship with exercise food and my body.

Food and exercise dominated my life. Every waking second (and sleeping) would be spent thinking about how I could avoid or compensate. I knew I had a problem for many years before I sought help. I was “functioning” on the surface, I was good at my job as a doctor and the personality traits that helped get me my career were so entwined with the the traits of the ED; perfectionism etc.

My eating disorder became a very unhealthy coping mechanism for any kind of stress or emotion I didn’t want to feel. I could “numb” out, but at the cost of numbing out everything. I finally reluctantly sought help when I was 30, when I realized I didn’t want to die, but I didn’t want to live in anorexia’s grips anymore. I confided in my husband when we were away on holiday and I was done being freezing and exhausted. He helped me seek treatment which I started upon our return. After nearly 3 years of various treatments I was in a good place 

Unfortunately, I relapsed after multiple failed  IVF treatments and an ectopic. I felt so ashamed and alone when this happened and an element of disbelief because I didn’t imagine I would ever fall back. It was so hard to accept and get “unstuck”. 

Something I wish was more openly talked about in the ED community is, pregnancy, pregnancy loss and infertility. All are such lonely experiences and not openly discussed in society and ED’s thrive on shame and secrecy. 

I re-entered treatment and have been making good steps since and I am so grateful for my supports for not giving up on me when I lost hope, for helping me to invest in myself and my recovery until I could find my hope again. 

If I could share any advice it would be to keep going, even when you don’t believe in recovery, let your supports help you and hold on to that hope. It does and will get better. It’s NEVER to late.

#edrecovery #eatingdisorderrecovery #recovery

There is no quick fix to recovering from an eating disorder, there is no one size fits all and I certainly don’t have all the answers but I wanted to share a few things that helped me a lot:

🌍 Identifying why I wanted to get well. The eating disorder had this way of making me feel, it made me feel like if I just kept doing what I was doing everything would be fine and work out. I know there are people living with eating disorders, functioning at a high level, perhaps you feel like that - still getting on with your life - but trust me when I say you aren’t really fully living. Think about why you want to get well, the why - it might be the energy, to not think about food… it could be anything but work it out! Write it out and stick it on key areas of your house! 

🫶Having space to work out what the eating disorder was about because it definitely wasn’t about food, or my body image. Ask yourself what’s going on? Identify those triggers and assess why is that a trigger for me…

📱Deleting all counting apps! 

✊Holding onto hope that I can recover! And when I don’t believe that, having people around me that do! 

Recovery from an eating disorder is hard-work but it also so so possible and so worth it!

Trigger warning ⚠️ sexual abuse 

⚠️⚠️⚠️

I have been thinking a lot the last few weeks about the recent allegations being made within the church around sexual assault and honestly I have found it triggering, upsetting and extremely frustrating. It actually shocked me how upset it has made me. And I think I only realised the extent of it when my older sister pointed out I was talking about it a lot, following it really closely each day. I am not going to judge the situation or people involved, but I wanted to bring it to light here because I am sure others have had some feelings towards it. 

When I think back to Soul Survivor, which I attended yearly until I was 17 and stopped going to church until a few years ago, I can’t help but relate to some of what I have read. But on top of this, I went to these camps after I had been sexually abused, I feel saddened that similar things were going on for others. And the shame I was feeling already from the abuse was often amplified with how topics about sex were talked about at these festivals so I kept silent. 

I know there will many of you who have experienced some sort of trauma in church or spiritual settings. But I want to remind you the church is made up of broken people it isn’t perfect, but the church isn’t God. 

Whatever your feelings are right now, I will be praying for you, but give yourself space to feel what you are feeling. 

Give yourself space to talk, pray, get angry.. give yourself space to journal, and if you are finding the news unhelpful either set yourself a timer so you don’t end up down a rabbit hole or cut it out altogether - please don’t let this derail you! 

❤️

A successful outing this afternoon with a picnic and to listen to live music and sit in the sunshine .. 

… what this picture doesn’t show is the the last 48 hours. A poorly baby, who vomited all over my clean hair and clean bed last night just before bedtime, a house which is drowning in laundry, toys everywhere and the remains of breakfast still sitting there on the side. 48 hours with practically no sleep as my tiny human wants constant cuddles… and me, stressed with work and the mental load. Worried that with Joshua’s sleep currently and is shyness round other kids that I have somehow failed him … 

… remember this weekend (and everyday!) when you are scrolling on social media, what we see isn’t always the reality! It’s a picture which may have be curated perfectly to portray the picture people want you to see because the reality is very few people are going to think to take a photo and share it when they are covered in baby sick …

Eating disorders have a really manipulative way of taking so many different opportunities to try and pull us back in. It can be exhausting, frustrating and at times the only option may feel like going back to those behaviours is the only way. Especially when we feel like they can give us an instant hit to dull that pain, take away that hurt and make us feel okay. But remember the eating disorder doesn’t solve anything. 

With this in mind, being aware of our triggers and the signs to look out for is so important! 
 
These will be unique to everyone - I would encourage you to identify yours and share them with someone so they are aware. 

For me I know that I have to be aware when:

🪧Rules around food and exercise start to dominate my thinking
🪧 When I develop a fear around a change of plan 
🪧When timings and routines become rigid 
🪧When I start ruminating over food 
🪧When I am thinking about food more
🪧When I am making excuses not to go to social activities 
🪧Cutting corners with meals 
🪧 Fixating on numbers 
🪧 When the narrative starts saying I would be happier if I changed this about me or did this behaviour 

Relapsing isn’t a sign of weakness, having these moments where patterns of behaviour try and pull us in isn’t weak but in those moments we need to reach out before cutting corners becomes bigger and sucks us back in. For me, reminding myself of how much the eating disorder ruined my life is key here, as well as focusing on what sort of future I want! 

What about you? What signs do you need to be aware of and What helps you stay in the road to recovery?

I listened to a brilliant podcast by @christinecaine  this morning all about purpose, focus comfort and obedience … 

And it really hit home with me not just with my faith but in my recovery too. It got me thinking about the amount of mistakes I have made along the way in my own recovery letting beliefs about food still dominate, letting fears hold me back. It makes me sad to think about how much of life I have missed out on because of the eating disorder, but I also believe not only can I turn this in to a positive to ensure others don’t do this and make the same mistakes but also that it’s never too late to turn things round. 

Now to preempt all this I want to emphasise eating disorders are not a choice and I have had some amazing therapy and people to help me and others don’t have this. 

In recovery from an eating disorder there seems to be so many reasons not to recover. So much that pulls us in from the false assurance, false comforts… false promises… and even as I write false, you are thinking it’s not false it feels amazing. And this I totally get! I thought I had this magical solution to all my pain in the eating disorder behaviours but the reality was it never solved anything but just kept me trapped. 

Maybe staying in the eating disorder feels like the safe option. Maybe it seems like the only way forward. 

Then something happens and we think it’s okay to do this behaviour I have been triggered, or one more time surely won’t harm me … but that one behaviour becomes another one, and another one … you will always find a reason not to recover. A fear that will appear at that crossroad decision when you sit down to a meal. The manipulative eating disorder that will dictate your next steps 

Please don’t make the same mistakes I made. You won’t regret sitting with the pain and saying yes to recovery 

I know it’s hard but trust that on the other side of fear of saying yes to embracing pain and healing that things can be amazing

On the other side of saying yes to recovery, and no to the eating disorder it will be okay! You can overcome this and use freedom!

First birthday yesterday with this little guy! We charged around the SS Great Britain with his cousins and then had a lovely lunch out with my family in my favourite restaurant on the harbour @bibloswraps …very grateful for my sister, mum and husband for sorting! 

… I find my birthday really hard each year and I am not entirely sure why. I think sometimes I feel sad that I have hit another year and I am not fully recovered. I think sometimes I have all this pressure that I put on myself to have this perfect day - the sort you see on social media. These emotions then mix at the same time with being grateful and proud of myself for still being here. I never thought I would have a baby let alone reach 33. 

Perhaps part of the messiness of birthdays for me is because I have memories of birthdays not being great growing up with arguments, especially throughout my time when the eating disorder dominated. 

It’s a messy day with a love / hate relationship and often one that I have to navigate mindfully especially with the narratives that often start up in my brain! And honestly this one felt harder this year - perhaps in light of all the allegations in the church, perhaps because I have a tiny human or perhaps because I didn’t organise anything with friends to mark the day … who knows! 

Anyway, I am just popping on to share some of my thoughts in the hope that it is helpful to others. And to remind you to lessen the pressure on life events because they don’t have one particular look!

Yesterday was just brilliant and I am still feeling so overwhelmed by it and have a lot of processing to do after it! 

I can’t thank you all enough for all your amazing support! 

I have often felt very isolated living in recovery from an eating disorder, often feeling quite separate from others, even at times ashamed of what I was feeling… so yesterday as well as if being amazing fighting the injustices and fighting for our rights. It also felt amazing to not feel alone!

Happy birthday to my tiny human! I can’t quite believe it’s been a year! 

A year with so many happy and amazing emotions but also some really hard bits! I have learnt so much about myself this year and have so many people that I feel so grateful to! 

Please remember this pic is one of my best moments - we didn’t take pictures of my tears, the sleepless nights (when we first had Joshua and before I start co-sleeping we would alternate who would be awake holding him in 3 hour intervals through the night!); I didn’t take pictures of the mountain of laundry after nappy explosions, or the narrative in my head telling me I am a rubbish mum and Joshua deserves better. But in all this I have learnt so much about myself! 

And 3 things I wanted to share that I learnt 

1) finding my why helped so much in recovery 

2) some babies don’t sleep and don’t take bottle and despite what society may tell us it doesn’t make us a failure! 

3) finding a happy thing in each day whether that’s a ticket machine for Joshua to play with, the sunshine on my face, finding awe and smiley things does the world of good!

Question - is it YOU or the eating disorder making the decision? 

Eating disorders are not a choice but when you sit down for your meals, when you look at a menu or when you go about your day with certain behaviours and hit a cross roads, who is in the driving seat? 

I know eating disorders aren’t a choice but throughout my recovery, there have definitely been moments where I have had to be honest with myself.  When I have to ask myself am I being me? Am I making a choice based on what I actually want from life or what the eating disorder wants? And don’t get me wrong it’s hard, feels impossible and relentless at times but there isn’t space for me to live my life fully with the eating disorder. 

I am sure some of you are sitting there feeling a bit nervous reading that. Feeling like I am being annoying by calling you out. And like I said, don’t get me wrong it feels really hard, and it is hard! It’s hard when everyone round us is doing one thing with food and we are doing the opposite. It feels hard when life is full of emotion and we just want to become numb. I have been there and honestly I still have moments when my brain is like “come on Hopes, I can take away the pain”. But the eating disorder can’t ever do that fully. It never delivers on what it promises and it wont make you happy. 

So today, when you are sitting there at a crossroads, focus on what future you want, focus on your reasons to recover and find a way to embrace the pain of this journey trusting that on the other side life it will be safe, secure and okay!

Aware I have been quite quiet on here this week … we have hit a bit of a moment with Joshua’s sleep… and he doesn’t really want to go to bed regardless of his naps, having a routine etc etc etc. before 9.30pm which is basically now when I go to bed too 😂🙈! He just wants to play a lot… we call it his wild pre bed hour! 

… I know it will be a phase and realistically in the next few weeks we will probably be back to our normal bedtimes but it has been quite hard in spaces mainly because society tells you they should sleep, and so I put on a load of pressure on myself and think I am doing it wrong … 

… anyway, it was interesting as I asked for some advice on a few groups I am part of and there is a 12 month sleep regression which probably explains most of this … but someone in the group said whilst we see it as a regression, see it as a developmental moment and exciting movements in your baby! 

… so last night at 8pm we headed to the park and had a play before coming back for a bath and bed! 

… so yes at the moment I may be slightly less on here until we get back to some sort of structure! But I am still here if you need anything ❤️

I have been feeling really horrid in my body the last few weeks and I am starting to notice it taking over slightly and know I need to stamp it out and work it through! 

The signs that I am aware of: 
💬the narrative in my head 
💬wearing the same clothes every day 
💬not washing my hair or taking care of myself 
💬being dismissive of how I feel 
💬being less present 

So whilst I have been mulling in it for a while now I need to do something about it before it takes over my mental health! So: 

👚 I am going to start getting dressed again  properly and not in the same clothes and taking time for me, washing my hair, making myself feel nice! This might seem superficial but it will help! 

❤️work out what’s really going on. I have talked a lot in the past about body image being a reflection for what’s going on feeling wise. And I know at the moment I have had some family & friends things going on so been feeling wrong in my body and I know that won’t be helping my body image so currently working through that and reminding myself that these issues aren’t because there is something wrong with me! 
(More on friendships and eating disorders another time!) 

🧠 Practising my mantras and interrupting my thought process when it gets bad! And focusing on what my body can do because that’s far more important than what it looks like! 

There is a lot more to unpack here and I am sure the hot weather isn’t helping the body feelings but more on that at some point! But to finish my thinking, one really key thing to remember is going back to the eating disorder behaviour will not solve any of this! 

📸 picture taken in the bathroom after Abel Tasman hike in New Zealand! A time when I was very good at focussing more on what my body can do not what it looks like!

“Enough is enough”, says @hopevirgo_ about the lack of support available for people experiencing eating disorders. Last month, Hope led a rally to Parliament Square as part of the #DumpTheScales campaign. Here she shares what the problem is and what change she wants to see.
A few Friday thoughts ❤️

Eating disorders have this way of making us feel, they pull us in promising us this sort of safety. Promising us that they will make everything okay… they tell us if we go down that route everything will be fine … and then that voice can get louder and louder …

Recovery is about changing the behaviours from those things that used to make you feel safe to the things that actually are safe and healthy… it’s about reaching out, naming what’s happening, it’s about knowing that the eating disorder won’t solve anything however much it’s beckoning you.. 

I know it’s hard when you are triggered, it’s hard when life feels too much and you just don’t want to feel. 

It’s hard when it all just feels relentless… but the eating disorder will NEVER solve anything! 

This week as you get challenged by things, if life feels hard please know that there are other solutions to life beyond the eating disorder. And please know that full recovery is possible!

This photo flashed up on my Facebook last night … it was back in 2019 and I had just won an award which I was and am so grateful for ..

… I stood there on stage smiling, but what they photo doesn’t show was what was actually going on and when I shared this pic before I never really explained … 

… I had sat in the bathroom before the event in floods of tears… I had had a hard few months with my sexual abuse case going through the courts and I was in the process of appealing the decision… relationships had broken down round me as I had tried to protect myself … and I had been working 24/7 as a way to just keep going…

… I was stood on this stage with a fear over what I had just eaten at the 3 course dinner, I remember looking at my plate trying to work out what I would have and trying so hard to be present - I was also feeling like a complete imposter and not deserving of the award… 

It’s all a bit of a jumble timeline wise, but around this time I had to find it in me to share honestly with friends about what was happening and I had to come up with a plan for how to get well again before things spiralled .. 

This photo for me is a mix of pure joy with the award to sheer sadness for what I was going through… and also a reminder a photo doesn’t tell the whole story!

On Tuesday afternoon, we were on our way back from soft play and I hadn’t had time to prep dinner for Joshua and me (my husbands away this week) and I was trying to work out in my head a quick speedy thing to do…. we got off the bus right by one of Joshua’s favourite places to get food! 

So a last minute decision and we picked up a takeaway! 

If I think back to the Hope even a few years ago a last minute takeaway would have thrown me completely. But not only that, but I would have not dreamed of doing something like this out of choice. My brain would have convinced me that with my husband away, it’s an easy excuse to not have something.. my brain would have panicked and started adding and adding, trying to justify whilst working out how to compensate… 

.. but not this time! Normalising having a Tuesday evening takeaway out of choice, last minute and when it’s us at home is a step forward I didn’t even realise I had to take in recovery! 

What’s your recovery feeling like this week and have you had any moments saying yes to recovery and no to the eating disorder?

Yesterday I had my final in person talk of the year at Royal High Bath. It was brilliant to do it in person speaking to all their students and brilliant to do a slightly different session speaking more about my campaigning! 

I am so grateful to all the schools and corporates who accommodated myself and Joshua and my husband this year so I could still do sessions with you all. And also very grateful to my husband for the support 

It’s been a really strange work year in so many ways and at times I have really struggled with the juggle. I am rubbish at asking to help and being so reliant on my husband and mum to either come to schools or sit with Joshua whilst I speak has been tough. When I was pregnant I had always planned to keep working a bit whilst on some sort of maternity leave, partly because freelance maternity pay is not great, partly because I didn’t want to stop campaigning and also partly because I was worried about my mental health if I didn’t work. I don’t share this lightly or for sympathy, but to remind you that everyone is different in how they do things! 

What I have learnt throughout the year, that asking for help is not weak or selfish and, that everyone has an opinion on how you parent and so you have to find a way to own who you are and be confident in that! 

I have also had to learn to manage the mum guilt which has been huge at times especially with work. But I know when I look at the facts behind these feelings, there isn’t a reason to feel guilty

There was a stage in my recovery from an eating disorder when I was ruminating and questioning everything. I felt stuck in this never ending cycling questioning my food choices, my clothes, my behaviours, and constantly ruminating with this fear of the unknown. Everyone kept saying trust me, trust the process, trust your body but how I can really trust anything when the fear is trapping me? How can I trust people when I feel so wrong in me? How can I trust people who maybe I have been 100% honest with? 

What if things don’t get better? What if I am set up to just have this life forever? 

What if people are lying to me about my intake, about my body? Who can I really trust? 

The questions were endless, and the thoughts in my mind relentless. Constantly worried, constantly thinking about food and the rules I had created. Constantly convinced I was present with friends but I wasn’t really there. 

Every time I saw my family I would quiz them on my body. And then message obsessively with follow up texts normally trying to catch them out. And honestly there were some days that whatever my mum said to me would be wrong!

I can totally feel the pain of these situations and moments with recovery. I don’t have all the answers to this but what I do know is:
1) from my experience, when I started to eat and listen to my body without any restricting, I ruminated less

2) the eating disorder wasn’t really about my body or the food so working out what was going on was key

3) getting to a space where I could predict bad body moments helped a lot so I could feel prepped

4) instead of said what if this happens, saying even if I will find a way through

5) I asked myself questions like “why does it matter if my weight goes up?”

6) I interrupted thought processes 

7) saying to people who loved me “I feel sad, I feel horrid and I hate this but I am trying” 

It’s hard, and these things won’t work for everyone but keep fighting! I am cheering you on

A lot of people have been in touch recently asking about pregnancy with an eating disorder and about how I navigated it as yes it can be really tough in spaces with an eating disorder - I am going to share some more things over the coming weeks and months but in the meantime. 

Here are 10 things I found helpful to get you started:

🪧Be honest with your midwives and health team! I know this can be hard but advocating for yourself to get the right support is key! 

🪧Be mindful of social media - stop comparing your bump to others! 

🪧 Assess what the eating disorder is trying to do. For me I knew the eating disorder was trying to numb emotion and fear, it was using my pregnancy as a chance to suck me back in offering me that instant relief but the more I was able to unpack that, the easier it got to stand up to it

🪧 Know what triggers you 

🪧 Know your worth. Putting yourself first in pregnancy is not selfish, know what your worth is and know that it is okay to push for additional support

🪧Set boundaries - When did it become OK for people to comment on someone else’s body? Answer – it didn’t. Communicate your boundaries clearly, explaining you don’t want unsolicited advice or body comments.

🪧 Surround yourself with the right people – those who cheer you on and make you feel good. The people who can call you out on behaviours through love

🪧Identify and name your fears and remember your motivations to stay well and be mindful of those who tell you that “you are doing it for the baby” If only it was that easy.. but some of us won’t find that very helpful!

🪧Keep eating and if some food feel to hard and make you feel sick, have something else! It’s hard adding in new things and variety but I found this helped me

🪧Invest in some maternity clothes, get dressed and keep your hygiene up! I know it’s hard when you feel rubbish but it will help!

A few weeks ago, I went on a podcast, and in the podcast we were having a chat about all things social media - the issues around people sharing meal pictures, those annoying posts showing what people eat in a day and also people sharing fear foods. And it got me thinking a bit more about where I am at with this all and what it looks like for me. 

Historically I have certainly been someone to share a lot of food pics to celebrate my recovery wins and I do still do it from time to time! I do it to bring you all in to these celebrations, and to hopefully encourage others too. I remember doing this weekly when I was doing my pastry challenge, but it got to a point where I was sharing because if I didn’t share I felt guilty after the food. Spoiler alert; there was still work that needed to be done on my own recovery. 

Beyond this, I began to worry that if I wasn’t sharing enough challenges then people wouldn’t think I was working hard at my recovery or that I wasn’t practising what I was preaching about! Wow social media can really be a bit of a messy place can’t it!? 

Anyway, I guess I wanted to come on here to say a few things (and yes this is rambling…) 

🥘 remember everyone has different fear foods so don’t compare yours to someone else’s! 

🪧If you find people sharing food recovery wins hard, mute them

🥘Whether online or in person, don’t compare your daily food to what someone else is having

🪧If you feel the need to post everything you are eating, ask yourself why? 

🥘Finally remember eating disorders aren’t about food! 

🪧🪧🪧

What I have found with social media it can be a hugely toxic place with regards to food and exercise  so please be mindful of the impact it may be having on you!

The last few weeks have been a bit of a blur in all honesty.. sleep deprivation and working on the next stage of #dumpthescales …

… and honestly a huge amount of frustration in places not just at the government, but also navigating freelancing with a baby and trying to gain some self worth back … but in light of this, it got me thinking about a 2 things! Firstly, how much we value ourselves… my self worth isn’t great - from working for free to not doing self care … I know I need to start to value myself more! 

Secondly, the importance of sleep! I have often sat in bed with Joshua whilst he has his nap and tried to plough my way through to do lists. Then getting tired and annoyed at myself for not doing as well as I could normally … 

… I wanted to share incase others relate to this but mainly to also just remind you to be kind to yourself! Have a sleep if you need one, slow down when you go out for a potter, stop and let the sun shine on your face 
….

🚨 CAMPAIGN UPDATE 🚨

On May 19th we delivered an open letter to the Prime Minister and then on May 20th hundreds of us came together to March for those affected by eating disorders! 

Since then I have been working hard to try and keep momentum going and I am so grateful to all of you who have helped by sharing posts, contacting your local MP and writing to the Prime Minister. The way to really change this is to keep making as much noise as possible so please keep sending these letters!!

Since the march, I hosted a roundtable with a number of MPs and external stakeholders where we discussed next steps and how to galvanise a proper commitment from all political parties! This is still in progress at the moment so I will keep you updated on how that is going! 

The next bit of exciting campaigning is #DumpTheScales went through the application process and has secured a spot in Parliament for one week to do a photo exhibition! I am so excited about this and that eating disorders will have a prominent place for everyone to see, telling so many different stories! The last few weeks I have begun gathering these and taking the portraits begins tomorrow! I am planning some additional activity round this exhibition so will keep you all posted on how as a community we can make a stand to end the injustices for those affected by eating disorders so please do watch this space! 

Thank you for all your support! I know it seems relentless in so many ways out there at the moment but we will make these changes happen because no one should be dying of an eating disorder or be condemned to a life of illness in 2023!

A teething baby at his second Bristol balloon fiesta (although last year he was so tiny not sure it counts) last night and it was lovely… 

… insta would have you think we sat on a rug,  soaking up the atmosphere, having food and drinks … we did take all this and it was a lovely evening, but we spent the whole time pottering round the observatory whilst Joshua explored! Trying to catch up with friends we bumped into whilst Joshua was desperate to break free 😂 And yes we had gone the night before too but there were no balloons 🎈 … our season right now is so different from anything we have known and honestly sometimes I feel like I am grieving past me but last night was one of those moments when I remembered how much I love our reality!

Thank you Daniella for sharing your story with us! 

💻💻

If I could pin point a moment when my eating disorder began it would be 10 years ago when I was 13 but I believe the development had began quite some time before so. 

I was always a happy, care-free child and loved my life of family and friends. I struggled significantly with my weight growing up and underneath my cheerful self I was very self-conscious, insecure and constantly comparing to myself to my peers. 
My parents separated when I was 9 and a few years later my mum, brother and I moved to Ireland where I began a new school and settled in well. 

In the summer of 2014, on holiday by the pool and feeling uncomfortable and embarrassed with myself I made the decision I was going to invest in a healthier version of myself. I very quickly became immersed into the ‘dieting world’ and changed my lifestyle really quickly. There is something about society that holds restrictive eating in admiration; we value self-control and thinness is seen in a similar regard.  This quickly became all-consuming and after presenting various worries my GP referred me to CAMHS. A thorough assessment lead to a diagnosis of Anorexia Nervosa and I was immediately taken out of school. Not having the choice to mix with my friends and knowing I would fall behind with school work significantly increased my anxiety and sent me into the depths of my eating disorder, it became my sole focus and I began to see no way out. 

Over the course of the next 2 years I was in and out of the general children’s ward and a child and adolescent mental health unit. Glimpse of recovery was closely followed by a relapse and my behaviours worsened each time. 

Due to shortages of beds in Ireland I was forced to return back to the UK at 17 to receive further inpatient treatment.

Cont below in comments 👇👇

Joshua found the Christmas decorations tonight in one of the cupboards (he’s currently obsessed with doors)! 

He loved exploring this box of sparkley things, but the smell of the tinsel honestly got to me. It resurfaced those memories of Christmas and the eating disorder. It’s no secret I still find the anticipation of Christmas hard and parts of the day too… and even the other day I found myself asking my sister and mum what the plan was! 

But tonight this smell got to me and I was trying to pin point exactly why! I think part of it is a worry that I am going to ruin Christmas for Joshua by not having a safe space to celebrate the way we want to with him. But I think beyond that with all the conversations around eating disorders at the moment and the relentless and battles that so many people are facing makes me feel for all of those individuals who may have the fear around what Christmas will look like. 

So tonight I want you to know that your loved one with an eating disorder may already have anxiety about Christmas and starting to work out a plan might just help that situation. Beyond that if you are someone who is worried, work out what works for you, work out what it looks like and know that Christmas can become an enjoyable time.

And remember it’s never too late to make new traditions!

This week I have heard more stories of clinicians, psychiatrists and those working with people affected by eating disorders that these people that are on their treatment teams are telling them “you won’t recover”, “you aren’t working hard enough,” “you will spend your life unwell…” “you have been ill for too long so we can’t help…” 

People working in healthcare need to hold on to hope for people, they need to look at what they can offer treatment wise that is individualised to that person to give them a chance to recover.. 

… people with eating disorders who do not respond to treatment should not be blamed, should not be shamed, but should be offered different treatments to help them! 

We cannot sit by and watch the injustices unfolding. We have a duty of care and a responsibility as a society to speak up, to make noise and to ensure what people affected by eating disorders no matter their age, gender, size, race can get support. 

It feels like a sad and dark time in the world of eating disorders at the moment, and whilst I hear good news stories of full recovery too and good treatment, I am hearing far too many stories dismissing patients, discharging them for the wrong reasons … 

Enough is enough! We need a world where everyone can access the right support and treatment - this isn’t a big ask, it’s a human right!

📸📸 Save the date!📸📸

From 16 October - 20 October 2023 we will be hosting a photo exhibition in Parliament: “Eating Disorders: Unheard Stories of a Hidden National Tragedy” 

At the exhibition you will see some powerful stories, hear about treatments and have the chance to add your name and thoughts to a board which will be delivered to the Prime Minister. 

This event is not just an exhibition; it’s a movement toward change, compassion, and healing, and we need your support to make it happen. Imagine immersing yourself in a world of stories that will touch your heart and open your eyes to the realities faced by those battling eating disorders. These unheard stories, the voices that have been silenced for too long, will finally have the chance to be heard loud and clear.

Let’s come together to raise awareness and eliminate the barriers that stand between those suffering and the help they need. Your support matters more than you know. The time to act is now! By having your photograph taken at the exhibition and sharing on social media with the #dumpthescales you’ll be declaring to the world that you stand with those affected by eating disorders. Your simple gesture of support will go a long way toward creating a ripple effect of compassion and understanding.
 
Eating disorders are not just personal struggles; they are a call for societal change. We refuse to accept that we’re falling behind in combating this national tragedy! 

Please do come and visit our exhibition in the Upper Waiting Room in the Houses of Parliament between 16&20 October, share your thoughts on the interactive board, and help us end the injustices of those affected by eating disorders!

social_posts.post_text:
A few weeks ago someone sent me new NhS guidance from the East of England.. and I am so pleased that the @telegraph has shone a spotlight on this disgraceful practice! But also extremely frustrated with how the nhs has lied even in this paper claiming they worked on this document with patients etc when they did not! 

The guidance says that patients as young as 18 who are at risk of dying from anorexia may be given palliative care rather than treatment to prolong life under new NHS guidance seen by the Telegraph.

The leaked document sets out how patients with severe eating disorders can be placed on a “palliative pathway”, with treatment no longer aimed at pursuing recovery through re-feeding.

Whilst it is important we nuance messaging around eating disorders and palliative care, we need to be aware that in so many situations people are not being given the chance to make a decision but instead having care withdrawn and being marked as untreatable. 

So many of us with eating disorders go through life feeling “wrong” in ourselves and by not giving us treatment and changing things up, it amplifies these feelings. 

There are multiple times I can think of when I would rather have died than been put through treatment, but not hear on the other side of it I am so grateful to the people who believed in me! 

We must keep fighting so that everyone can get the right care and treatment because no one should be dying of an eating disorder in 2023!

I have been thinking a lot about my life when I was in the grips of anorexia…

… Perhaps it’s because I have felt triggered in some ways, perhaps because I am pushing to be totally well, or maybe because when my mood is a bit low I project it onto my body so my body image gets worse… and then I long for a way to switch off the pain…

…  even with the link to my emotions projecting on to my body, for me my eating disorder was never about body image, it was about numbing those emotions, the pain, the things I didn’t want to feel. It took me out of the reality of facing so much of what the world was throwing my way, and all those things I didn’t really want to feel or face..

.. No one chooses to have an eating disorder but sometimes I find it helpful to remind myself of what I lost at that time…

… You might look at someone with an eating disorder and think you want to be back there…

… you might also look on at people and think they are functioning & living life with an eating disorder… and that can play into that narrative that we can do whatever we want with an eating disorder (spoiler alert - we can’t!)

… in those feelings of numbness & what the anorexia fails to remind you as you long for that, is all the other stuff that comes along side it - The fact you can’t think about anything other than food 90% of the time; that you can’t engage in conversations properly, you don’t have the energy to do things whether going out with friends or laughing. I think back to my illness and I was gripped by fear. Gripped in this space where I was convinced I was okay, that I was happy but I wasn’t. I was cold, tired, unable to really live fully. I cried most evenings laying in bed on my own. Everything took so much effort, and I had fears of what would happen if there was a last minute change of plan, I wanted to lay in bed all day to gain some energy but my brain wouldn’t let me… I missed out on holidays, ruminated over calories when I stood at the bar ordering drinks, I was trapped and saw no way out..

.. whatever the eating disorder promises you, please know it is all lies! And whilst recovery is so hard, it is also so possible
Don’t lose hope and don’t believe anyone who says you are too unwell to recover x

For as long as I can remember I have felt extremely body conscious, and throw in some hard days mentally, diet culture and no movement and it all becomes amplified! 

When we arrived in Palermo last Sunday I was determined to throw myself into swim wear and engage in the moment with Joshua! And that’s exactly what I have done! 

Yes I have felt uncomfortable at points and panicked a bit but I want Joshua to grow up with different bodies and to not feel self conscious in his own skin! And one way of doing that (I think) is embracing me! 

So yes! These are to the memories we are making and letting all my skin be hit by sunshine and distracting myself from feeling self conscious! 

For me, life feels too short to not wear my bikini and throw myself into sand holes we build!

So grateful to Harriet for sharing some or her writing with us! 

❤️

Dear anorexia, my enemy, 

You have to distorted my view upon the world and basically paralysed me. You are more like a parasite to me. I’m shattered, I’m tired and I’m tired of being tired, I feel like your puppet in a show being dangled. You manipulate me with your powerful strings in a trance manner. My vision is now overtaken by your looming fog creating grey hazy bleak days. 

How the heck did you get so powerful anorexia? You convince me if I enjoy anything, such as food or going out in the evenings, I need to be punished and therefore restrict my life. I’m sick of being forced to act in certain ways by you. Seeing my life as a range of mathematical equations. 

You disconnected me from people I love the most. You bully and tease me every time looked in the mirror and see a photos and videos of myself. You trick me into thinking food, self-care, different activities, hobbies, friendships, relationships are pointless because I deserve punishment. You made me dread the moment I wake and make me count down the hours until bedtime every day, as days feel like torture. 

You consumed my brain with utter lies and constant worries filling me with fear that riddled my body. You make me feel like I am useless, weird, a freak, never good enough and a complete burden upon everyone. I can never forgive you for that. I strained my relationship for you. You make me feel like I can’t trust anyone in my life but in reality I can. I will never forgive you for the loneliness, the exhaustion, the starvation you cause me. 

Every time I look in the mirror I hear you, every time I eat I hear you, every time I miss exercise I hear, you every time I try and go out with my friends or family I hear you especially in the evenings I hear you so loudly. 

Cont in comments 👇

It’s certainly been a weekend with lots of different segments & very little sleep 🙈 … but despite the lack of sleep it has also been lovely with so many recovery wins! And just embracing life! 

People often ask me, am I fully recovered from anorexia and the answer is no. I believe full recovery is possible, but I think I still have a few percent to go to hit that point! And no I don’t know how that will 100% feel but I know the freedom will be amazing! Part of the reason I do have a little way to go is I still have some internal healing, some trigger points and some beliefs around food. None of these are a choice but I have to choose to challenge things! 

For me it’s about keeping up the momentum with where I have got to even though there are times when the eating disorder tries to pull me back in! 

It’s about keeping up the food challenges, it’s about talking, identifying triggers, distracting my brain when it ruminates … 

… I don’t know where you are at right now, or how you feel about your own recovery but please don’t lose hope. You can break free from the eating disorder too! You can have freedom! It’s not easy, it’s relentless, hard and a battle but you can get there! Repeat it loud and clear - “I can beat this!” 

And one day soon you will look back and see how far you have come … but in the meantime don’t let the eating disorder lure you in with false promises telling you to cut corners and take risks with ED behaviours because trust me when I say that can be detrimental to us! 

Sending you so much love this Sunday evening!

Please meet Rosie who has recently been discharged from treatment. 

Her mum told us: 

Rosie deteriorated rapidly and I could see we were losing our beautiful girl. It was like she was being taken hostage. This horrible illness has robbed Rosie of her childhood and has caused significant trauma to herself and to her 12 year old sister. We now have hope but there is so much I wish we could have changed. I wish the doctor had seen her, I wish we had been seen by CAMHS earlier, I wish the hospital had a better understanding of Eating Disorders and that we hadn’t had to take Rosie to the UK.

📝📸📝📸

Thank you for sharing your story! Eating disorders can impact anybody and we have to make a stand to end the injustices that many are facing all over the UK!

Eating disorders are not about body image! But in recovery we often have to work out our body image, work out our emotions what we have projected onto our bodies and unpick what’s going on!

I had a 15 minute window to get dressed and ready for the launch tonight whilst Joshua finished up his nap and I put on what I had planned to wear and felt disgusting. 

The jumper felt too tight, the skirt seemed to dig in .. I have got so used to hiding my body with baggy clothes that something fitted just felt ugh! (More on this later!) 

I stood there looking in the mirror and reminded myself that right now the eating disorder wants to sabotage the event tonight, it wants me to lose my confidence so that it doesn’t go to plan … in the past I had always spent time predicting what the eating disorder would say at events like this but today I hadn’t done that! This is something that has really helped historically and I massively recommend it! 

So this is my reminder to you that 

🪧eating disorders will do anything the can to suck you back in but don’t let them!

🪧 when your body image is bad what’s actually going on? What are your projecting onto it? 

🪧 have your mantras in your head to keep you going! 

🪧 Christians remember john 10v10 (this just popped into my head so think it’s for me and also for others!) 

🪧 Remember body size is the least interesting thing about us & no one else will be looking or caring what we look like!

Meet @elliesmiith and Nicky who shared their experiences for the photo exhibition! 

📸📝📸📝

Ellie’s Story 

Anorexia. Where to even begin. I try now to be as open and honest as I can about this vile illness, try to spread awareness but sometimes I find myself struggling to even put into words about how this has affected the last 11/12 years of my life, and so many others I know. I am 25 years old, but a 25 year old who has certainly not led a ‘normal’ life. I have spent more time in hospital over the years; including general hospitals (who do not have a single clue how to treat eating disorders), adolescent inpatient, private day care services, acute MH wards for my safety (due to this illness quite literally driving me to the point of suicide attempts), and many, many adult SEDU admissions, to currently being in an eating disorder rehabilitation placement. 

I have seen and experienced things that at the age of 25 most people haven’t / won’t experience in a lifetime. I have so much trauma due to Anorexia, and now have a diagnosis of EUPD because of my experiences and trauma. I have lost friends, damaged relationships, completely destroyed my body. No one tells you (or at least when so entrenched your anorexic brain will not listen to) about the complications chronic Anorexia can have on the human body. I have osteoporosis, cardiac complications and problems, a bowel/bladder that barely works, and who knows if I can ever have children. Unfortunately I am once again, stuck in the cycle of relapse/‘recovery’. I can rationally say it is an ongoing cycle of losing weight to then being made to gain it back. But it’s so much more than that – and it’s an extremely hard cycle to break. Painful. Torturous. It seems impossible. 

Anorexia is not just about the food, or the wanting to be ‘skinny’, that never even crossed my mind. I did not develop my Anorexia because I went on a diet. The reasons I developed it we are still trying to figure out 11 years later through countless methods of therapy.

Cont below 👇

Recovery today was unplanned s’mores with my tiny human at Forest School. 

I think so much of the time people who haven’t experienced an eating disorder take things like this for granted. The last minute meal changes, random snacks in the day, changes up in routine as something that just is what it is. But when you have had an eating disorder (and whilst they are not just about food!) it can be these small changes which are recovery wins in themselves! 

This morning we had one of those moments. When Joshua cooked s’mores (see his face of concentration when you swipe right). 

The Hope of old wrapped up in the anorexia would have worried, a last minute snack, what’s exactly in it, are those sainsbury marshmallows with X calories in or coop ones with X calories in. I would have stressed about it, and ruminated if I had had it, but if I hadn’t had it would have thought about it all day. And also felt guilty when Joshua wanted to give me some and I had said no. 

But today; like most days,  in my recovery now I had some with him and made a happy memory. And even when my brain is difficult afterwards I am able to sit with those thoughts, not compensate and keep going! 

I say it time and time again, recovery is hard and painful but so possible! And full recovery is 100% possible!

Over the last few weeks I have been trying really hard at recovery and shifting this final eating disorder mindset. For me this has looked like saying yes daily to recovery. Even things that at the time weren’t a scary thing or seemingly a big deal saying yes when I know the eating disorder would have said no has been key! 

From last minute lunches at my mums house so I can eat what Joshua is having, to saying yes to the biscuit at playgroup to eating what I actually want when I am hungry. 

I have found for so long my brain can easily talk me out of these things - it says “you don’t need that snack.” Or “why don’t you just choose something easier?” “Why do you say yes to that biscuit when no one else is bothered?” … but what I learnt with anorexia since starting my recovery is it has an excuse, a reason why to not doing something, and yes the safe easy option maybe what I think is best, but that isn’t going to help me!!! 

So have the snack, say yes to what you really want, order the side you want in a restaurant.. I promise you whilst it’s hard it’s worth it!

One question I get asked a lot is “what would you say to your younger self?” 

I was asked this question recently and maybe in light of now having a tiny person who I love so much, it made me more emotional thinking about the answer. What are those things I felt as a child that I would never ever want Joshua to feel. Those feelings of shame, feeling wrong … but some of these feelings and narratives maybe I still hold onto too much… 

So to anyone who is hurting right now I say to you that “Freedom is possible!” I tell you “not to lose hope as things can change, keep going and trust that on the other side of fear things can be really good.” 

I want you to remember “that you are enough, that you are matter and you would be missed if you weren’t here.” 

I want you to hold on to the truth that “there is nothing wrong with you and you will enjoy life again!”
