Meet Mollie who was recently photographed for the Eating Disorders Exhibition: Unheard Stories, a national tragedy

📸📝📸📝📸📝

 My name is Mollie Twitchell, I am 23 years old. I was diagnosed with anorexia when I was 12 years old when I was first admitted to a private hospital in London and at this point I didn’t really know what was going on. That day was when everything changed. I didn’t have any understanding of what anorexia really was or the connection between what I was doing to my body and the impact it had on my overall health. There were a lot of changes going on in my life at that age, moving to a secondary school, my parents separated at this time, I started puberty which I didn’t manage very well, being a high achiever in everything I did where I put a lot of pressure on myself to succeed. I just wasn’t coping with life and myself. I couldn’t control what was happening around me, I just felt out of control with myself and I didn’t know how to communicate the internal struggle I was facing. 
I struggle with perfectionism and this gradually got worse over time as I got older and as the illness itself got more severe. I came from a very sporty childhood where my siblings and I took part in a lot of competitive sports. I was doing a lot of training and wasn’t managing to have the right nutrition alongside. At this age I was trying to manage so much and deep down I wasn’t really happy and felt lost. Nothing I did felt good enough and I also never felt good enough as a person. I based my worth on the grade I got in school or what I won in my sport events or if people liked me. I wanted my family to be proud of me and I was so scared of failing because I always felt like I did something wrong if I didn’t do well or that I was incapable if I didn’t get the top grade and people would be disappointed in me. When this happened I punished myself in many ways, food and exercise became something that I turned to in order to cope.

In the past 10 years I have been in and out of multiple inpatient hospitals across different counties since I was first diagnosed at 12.

Cont 👇

Just because someone may look okay, it doesn’t mean they are!

Over the course of my Hospital admission I went from being desperate to leave hospital in those first few weeks to being completely terrified as my discharge date came around. I didn’t feel remotely ready. How was I going to eat outside of hospital when I wasn’t being encouraged to. How was I going to manage without having someone there to quiz about any sort of change to food, my body or my mood … And what if the eating disorder began to dominate again? By the time I was being discharged there was a big part of me that wanted to stay well so I was afraid of not having the support. But imagine juggling that want to stay well with that eating disorder part that wanted to seduce me back? That would be there at every opportunity reminding me that this discharge was a chance to start restricting again. 

I was by no means fully recovered when I was discharged, and looking back my weight was still too low so my brain wasn’t full required and repaired, but we can’t stay in treatment forever I had to take the plunge and see. 

So what helped me (and remember this is off the back of treatment, and my own personal advice!) 

📝Stuck to a meal plan - I did this for the first three years or so! 

📝Hold onto my motivations - mainly at the start not being admitted back to hospital 

📝Be aware of wha things might trigger me and have a plan in place for them! 

📝Have mantras in my head for those days when life feels messier 

📝No matter how bad my body image gets always eat, shower and get dressed 

📝Know where I could turn to for support! Friends, family or helplines! 

📝Have someone to check in with every few weeks (or as much as you need!) 

📝Focus on the positives of recovery! And name the negatives of the eating disorder for those moments when it tries to romanticise how it made us feel! 

📝Surround yourself with the right people and set boundaries with those who don’t help your recovery! 

📝Be mindful of social media and diet culture! 

 I always make it so easy, and it isn’t. Recovery is one of the hardest things I have ever done. And being discharge from support throws up a lot so take what you need from this list and add anything else that helps you below!

The last 2 nights on holiday, I have hated my dinners! We picked places that would work for Joshua and normally that works just fine for me and I am in a space where I can make most restaurants work. But the last two nights, it just hasn’t worked!

The thing with anorexia (for me) is I spent so long in that mindset that if I didn’t like the meal, I somehow had wasted calories and that was just the worst thing in the world. I felt annoyed at myself that this mattered to me so much when others could just have a meal they didn’t enjoy and move on. When the meal arrived last night I was so frustrated. It wasn’t what I had predicted from the menu. 

Years ago the anorexia would have said to me “just have something later” “say you don’t like it” … and as I looked down at it last night I was flooded with so many thoughts but instead of allowing them to dominate I ate my meal, felt a bit rubbish, then sat on a step playing cars with Joshua whilst my husband finished off his meal. 

I know in 6 months time even though the anorexia would try and get me to pinpoint on the meal, that the evening memories of playing with Joshua, charging round the beach would be stronger than anything else. 

Meals in recovery from anorexia aren’t happy clappy, they aren’t Instagram picture perfect, they can be messy but don’t let the eating disorder create that narrative in your head that you have wasted calories if the meal isn’t perfect to you! Food is so much more than numbers, it’s connection, memories, laughter… 

.. sending love to anyone who is ruminating over those specific meals whether from today, yesterday or 6 months ago .. journal your thoughts, pray it through if you have a faith and focus on what else that meal provided for you

Eating disorders are NOT a choice but a hard food day the day before, a hard brain day, messy news, difficult emotions, bad body image, someone saying we look “healthy” … [insert your emotion or trigger] … are not excuses to resort back to eating disorder behaviour because these behaviours whilst promise so much will NOT solve anything! 

I know that sounds easy to say and perhaps everything I do does as it often ignores the messy bit, the pain, the emotions, sitting in the unknown, the narratives we have, the way society is …

… trust me I know how unbelievably hard it is to ride out these emotions and how hard recovery is but what I can 100% promise you is resorting to the eating disorder behaviours will not solve anything. Please try and trust me when i say that! 

Life is hard, but eating disorders won’t solve anything! 

Sending a whole load of love to all of you today. I know it’s hard and you might feel defeated but keep going. You are a fighter and can be free

A huge thank you to Emily for sharing your story with us! 

📝📸📝📸📝

I’d say my eating disorder came along around 2 years prior to my diagnosis - during my early teenage years. The safety blanket it initially provided for me filled me with a sense of euphoria and provided a focus in my life - I felt invincible - which is why I believe I fell so deeply into its trap.

My relationship with my eating disorder quickly turned sour. Anorexia tortured me, every minute, of every day. It has done since. 

I soon found myself drained of all happiness, socially withdrawing, falling behind in class and physically weak but despite this never ending list of symptoms, I wouldn’t admit that there was anything wrong. 

The truth is some days I liked it. I never felt alone. I was safe. 

Until one day I wasn’t anymore. 

The manipulation anorexia masks as a friend hides the truth from sufferers. Anorexia is not your friend. She’s a bully and will do whatever it takes to stop you from achieving your full potential. 

I’ve been attending treatment since the day of my diagnosis and whilst it’s not been an easy journey, it is by far the most worthwhile thing I have done in my life. 

I’m proud to say I was completely discharged from Adult’s Eating Disorder services in January this year and have achieved so much more in my recovery than I could’ve ever imagined.

I have just begun my first year as a medical student at King’s College London. 

I hope to use my story as a message to others that it does get better and that recovery really is possible, no matter how hard it seems. 

As my doctor once said to me:

“Right now your world is your eating disorder. There is nothing else. My job is to make your world seem bigger than your eating disorder, to show you how much there is to be seen, to be done. Your time is not over yet. Today marks the start of your life.”

From my teens, the build-up to Christmas, the smell of the tree – I hated it. I hated everything it brought with it. There was fear in the run-up to the day itself with all that food just sitting round. What if I couldn’t control myself? What if I just ate everything?

No one saw what was really going on – the panic from mid-way through the year that only heightened as we got closer to Christmas. 

I am 33 now, but having lived with anorexia since I was 13, this has been the way I have spent and felt about most Christmases each year for over half my life.

Even as my recovery began, I started to feel pressure not to “ruin the day” for everyone else.

And I often had those feelings that I was “wrong” which is why things were like this. 

Christmas was and can be still to some extent a minefield. I hope that you can know that you aren’t alone in how you feel. 

And beyond knowing you are not alone. Remember people with eating disorders can and do recover, so this Christmas, hold onto the hope that things can change and you can be free too! 

And if that feels too far away and too wishy washy, why not find a few things that make you smile this festive season?

I never know whether to share these posts on here but in light of all my campaigning, we have to share the realities that so many are facing at the moment. Thank you so much to those who have shared your stories with me to help others feel less alone. And to help make sure we can put an end to this inhumane treatment. 

No one with an eating disorder should be dying but due to the decades of stigma, underfunding, staffing issues and lack of evidence based treatment  we are seeing so many people being marked as untreatable. This is not the fault of those working in the NHS but goes beyond them! 

If you haven’t already please do help us end the injustices of those affected by eating disorders by writing to your local MP, and by adding your name to the #dumpthescales campaign 

The situation for those with eating disorders right now and their carers, friends and families feels dark and scary but please don’t lose hope that people can and do recover and we will keep fighting for change until everyone has the right support!

Christmas Day at my Dad’s yesterday done! 

I would be lying if I said I had found it easy in the build up - maybe partly with divorced parents there is often a lot of emotion riding on these occasions. (For me anyway!) 

My wonderful older sister texted me last night to check in and say well done which really helped with how I was feeling! Remember these sort of messages following and ahead of certain days can really help! 

It got me thinking about the pressure generally on Christmas. The pressure to “be okay”, the pressure to have “the best time”… showcasing on social media what we want people to see … 

… in the midst of the pressure and heightened emotion why don’t you find those moments that make you smile. Mine was Joshua following his cousins up a stream and then copying as they launched sticks to splash into it!

I sat down to write a post this morning all about navigating the week pre Christmas which I will share later but as I was writing it I was just thinking do you know what this sucks. Christmas for so many people sucks. And I mean not just the “this sucks” casually but this is proper relentless and hard. The feeling that it is just too much. And maybe like me you are doing what you can to make it work to set it up to be successful, to set those boundaries and to try and put yourself first. But in reality it’s just not necessarily working for you and it feels too painful. 

If that’s you, I want to send you so much love and let you know I am praying for you right now. 

The thing about recovery from an eating disorder is there is no short cut, there is no 5 simple steps to get there. And that is the same for Christmas. Yes we can make it more manageable but it still might hurt in spaces. But what I can assure you is when we get through the pain of recovery from an eating disorder, through the emotion, the other side can be safe. 

So this year, keep reminding yourself that these feelings can pass. I know it doesn’t feel like it now but it will be okay. I promise you it can be. So please don’t lose hope, please trust me x

This final week pre Christmas can be hard, emotions everywhere, pressures we may be putting on ourselves, and people rushing round doing last minute shopping. Whilst at the same time trying to curate a certain image to portray … and for those affected by eating disorders can feel like an added minefield. From fear of carers that they aren’t going to find what their loved one wants to eat, to trying to protect that person. To the individual themselves who feel fearful about the next few days. I know historically for me I would often go between burying my head in the sand to counting everything, calculating and trying to numb emotions through eating disorder behaviours but as I always say that does not solve anything. 

So what am I going to do this week (well try to do as I am not always great at looking after me). Remember I am not a therapist so  sharing this from lived experience so take what you need and add anything else that helps you below: 

❄️ Prioritise quiet time: for me this is journaling, praying, reading my Bible and having space to unwind each day

❄️ Have a plan in place for the whole week and days following Christmas Day and this might include a back up plan if things feel a bit more messy! 

❄️ Predict what my brain will do on Christmas Day and the days after, then identify a healthy and well way to respond!

❄️ Be mindful of my social media usage 

❄️ Know my mantras for Christmas Day 

❄️ Tell someone if I am finding things hard - this doesn’t have to be a huge message but could just be “I am not okay” - naming it can really help! 

❄️ Book some nice things in for in between Christmas and New Year 

❄️ Decrease the pressure we put on ourselves!

Sending so much love ahead of the next week of activity!

We got the train to Bath this morning and I noticed so many people on the train with their presents no doubt heading to where they are spending this Christmas season. So many emotions for so many people with this uncertainty and perhaps fear of what the next few days will hold. Those with the dread as they approach a situation where they may not feel any safety, or where they are missing a loved one. Those who are worried about what people will say, comments on food or bodies and the fear of those who just don’t get it. I totally get this, and I do still have some of the anticipation around some of my plans as I sit here now with Joshua sleeping on me. My brain ruminating and fearful of what some of the days of festivities will look like. Plus the pressure that things need to be perfect for others.

I thought back to those times I had returned home when at university, those trips for Christmas when I was so unsure what was going to happen and how it would play out.
If you feel this fear, the heightened emotions, please know that you are not alone. Please know the feelings pass and please keep yourself safe. 

I know that there is not always anything we can say to help alleviate the pain in these moments but I am praying for you all and sending so much love. 

Please know, if you find this season hard there is nothing wrong about you.  x
